abstract.text: Define 3D objects by constructing meshes.

inlineContent.text: To create a 3D object, create a
You can manually create an array of
Euclid offers a number of helper methods to quickly create complex geometry.
The simplest way to create a
is to start with an existing primitive, such as a cube or sphere.
The following primitive types are available in Euclid, and are defined as static constructor methods on
(or cuboid, if you specify different values for the width, height and/or depth).
instances are made of flat polygons.
Since true curves cannot be represented using straight edges, the

parameters to configure the level of detail.

, but with equal width and height.
- A regular polygon shape (not to be confused with Euclid’s
Geometric primitives are all very well, but there is a limit to what you can create by combining spheres, cubes, etc.
As an intermediate step between the extremes of using predefined primitives or individually positioning polygons, you can use
The following builders are defined as static constructor functions on the
to create a strip or tube. A second variant (

and rotates it around the Y-axis to create a rotationally symmetrical
. This is an easy way to create complex shapes like candlesticks, chess pieces, rocket ships, etc.
and extrudes it along its axis, or another path. This can turn a circular path into a tube, or a square into a cube etc.
instances and joins them. The sequence of
instances do not need to be the same shape, but must all have the same number of points and subpaths. To work correctly, each
must be pre-positioned in 3D space so they do not all lie on the same plane.

instances. But unlike the other builders, in addition to paths you can also form a convex hull around a collection of meshes, polygons, vertices or points.
Builders are a powerful tool for creating interesting

curves come in. Beziers allow you to specify complex curves using just a few control points.
Euclid exposes this feature via the
property is used to calculate surface normals (for lighting purposes), but with the

as normal, but curved ones are treated as off-curve Bezier control points.
method controls how many line segments are used to approximate the curve.
method uses second-order (quadratic) Bezier curves, where each curve has two on-curve end points and a single off-curve control point.
are used in sequence then an on-curve point is interpolated between them.
It is therefore  possible to create curves entirely out of curved (off-curve) control points.
This approach to curve generation is based on the popular
, and provides a good balance between simplicity and flexibility.
For more complex curves, on macOS and iOS you can create Euclid
supports cubic bezier curves as well as quadratic.
CSG is another powerful tool for creating intricate geometry.
CSG allows you to perform boolean operations (logical AND, OR, etc.) on solid shapes.
The following CSG operations are defined as methods on the
- Produces a shape representing the non-overlapping parts of the input
es (this is useful for rendering text glyphs).
es, removing internal faces and leaving only the outer shell around both shapes (logical OR).
representing the common volume of two intersecting
- This creates a convex hull around one or more meshes.
- This traces the edges of one mesh with another.
es that are “watertight”, that is they have no holes in their surface.
Using a CSG operation on a mesh that isn’t sealed may result in unexpected results.
On macOS and iOS you can make use of Euclid’s Core Text integration to create 2D or 3D extruded text.

Each glyph in the input string maps to a single
Glyphs formed from multiple subpaths will be filled using the even-odd rule (equivalent to using
with the individually filled or extruded subpaths).

abstract.text: Euclid is a library for creating and manipulating 3D geometry using techniques such as extruding or “lathing” 2D paths to create solid 3D shapes, and CSG (Constructive Solid Geometry) to combine or subtract those shapes from one another.
A finite line segment in 3D space.
A 3D surface made of polygons.
Creates a conical mesh.
Computes the convex hull of a set of points.
Returns a new mesh representing a convex hull around the
mesh parameter and the receiver, with inner faces removed.
Creates an axis-aligned cuboidal mesh.
Creates a cylindrical mesh.
Creates a mesh by extruding one path along another path.
Efficiently extrudes an array of paths along their respective face normals, avoiding duplicate work.
Efficiently fills an array of paths, avoiding unnecessary work if there are duplicates.
Creates a mesh by filling a path to form one or more polygons.
Returns a new mesh representing the volume shared by both the mesh
parameter and the receiver. If these do not intersect, an empty mesh will be returned.
Creates a rotationally symmetrical mesh by turning the specified path around the Y axis.
Creates a mesh by connecting a series of 3D paths representing the cross sections.
Returns a new mesh representing the Minkowski sum of the
mesh parameter and the receiver.
Creates a spherical mesh.
Returns a new mesh that retains the shape of the receiver, but with
the intersecting area colored using material from the parameter.
Efficiently strokes a collection of line segments (useful for drawing wireframes).
Creates a mesh by stroking a path with the line width, detail, and material you provide.
Returns a new mesh created by subtracting the volume of the
mesh parameter from the receiver.
Efficiently XORs multiple meshes.
Creates an extruded text model from a string.
Returns a new mesh representing the combined volume of the
mesh parameter and the receiver, with inner faces removed.
A path made up of a sequence of straight line segments between points.
Creates a closed circular path.
Creates a quadratic bezier spline.
Creates a closed elliptical path.
Deprecated.
Creates a closed regular polygon.
Creates a closed rectangular path.
Creates a rounded rectangle path.
Creates a closed square path.
Creates an array of glyph contours from an attributed string.
A point along a path.
A Boolean indicating whether the point is curved or sharp.
A polygon in 3D space.
Display the 3D shapes you created with meshes.
